Comment: Nice clash, easy enough to understand even in Reverse. Good test cases.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice super-speedy clash of code
You should remove the trailing newline from the output of Validator 4.

Goal
* Please define which letters are considered vowels. (Note: In some clashes, the letter "Y" is treated as a vowel.)

Constraints
* "string.printable" seems to be a Python-specific term. Instead, please state that all characters in [[s]] are standard ASCII characters. If you want to be more precise, you may mention that for all characters in [[s]], 32 â‰¤ ASCII value â‰¤ 126.

Cases
* Each test and its corresponding validator should be similar. See below for the changes to make.

* Test 1: Please add one or more digits to [[s]].

* Test 2: Please include all vowels in both lowercase and uppercase.

* Validator 2: Please also include all vowels in both cases, but use a different input string from Test 2.

* Test 3: Please include all consonants in both lowercase and uppercase.

* Validator 3: Please also include all consonants in both cases, but use a different input string from Test 3.

* Validator 4: Please include a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, and add a few punctuation characters to [[s]].

Thanks.
Made all requested changes! Thanks for the check!

Thank you for the update! The revised cases are getting closer, but some of them still need adjustments:

* Test 2: Please include all vowels in uppercase too.

* Validator 2: Please include all vowels in lowercase too.

* Test 3 and Validator 3: Please include all consonants in the missing case too. The simplest way is to combine the two input strings in different order (e.g. uppercase + lowercase for Test 3, lowercase + uppercase for Validator 3).

Thanks again.
Thank you again for your patience! I believe I have updated the test cases as requested!
Many thanks for your quick follow-up ðŸ˜‰
